translated: Birth Stories
The Group of Sixes
The Chapter on the Unprotected
The Birth Story of Sirikāḷakaṇṇi
“What is it that you are so dark,
and yet so lovely to behold?

original: Kā vā tvaṁ kassa vā dhītā,
analyzed: kā vā tvam kassa vā dhītā
translated: Whose daughter are you? Whose child?
How can we know you?”
“I am the daughter of the Great King,
Virūpakkha, the fierce one.
I am Kāḷī, the unlucky one,
Kāḷakaṇṇī, the wise ones know me.
Ask for a favor and give it to me,
I will live in your presence.”
“What kind of character, what kind of conduct,
do you settle on in a man?
Tell me, Kāḷi, when asked,
how can we know you?”

analyzed: makkhī paḷāsī sārambhī  issukī maccharī saṭho
translated: “The one who is deceitful, contemptuous, quarrelsome,🔽envious, stingy, and crafty,
he is the man I love,

original: laddhaṁ yassa vinassati.🔽Kodhano upanāhī ca,🔽pisuṇo ca vibhedako;
analyzed: laddham yassa vinassati  kodhanaḥ upanāhī ca  pisuṇaḥ ca vibhedakaḥ
translated: who will lose what he has gained.🔽The angry, the spiteful,🔽the slanderer, the divider,
the one with harsh words,
he is even more dear to me than that.
The man who says ‘today is good,’
does not understand his own good.
When advised, he gets angry,
he despises a better man.
The man who is carried away by desire,
destroys all his friends.
He is my beloved man,
I am well in him.”
“Go away from here, Kāḷī,
this is not found among us;
Go to another country,
to a town or a capital city.”
“I know that too,
this is not found among you;
There are those in the world who are not generous,
who gather up much wealth;
I and my brother, the god,
we will both destroy it.”
“What is your divine beauty,
firmly established in the world?

original: Kā vā tvaṁ kassa vā dhītā,
analyzed: kā vā tvam kassa vā dhītā
translated: Who are you? Whose daughter are you?
How can we know you?”
“I am the daughter of the Great King,
of the glorious Dhataraṭṭha;
I am Sirī and Lakkhī,
the wise know me as Bhūripaññā;
Having asked for an opportunity,
we can live in your presence.”
“In what kind of virtue, in what kind of conduct,
do you place a man?
Having been asked, Lakkhī, tell me,

original: Kathaṁ jānemu taṁ mayaṁ”.🔽“Yo cāpi sīte atha vāpi uṇhe,
analyzed: katham jānemu tam maya  yaḥ u ca api sīte atha vā api uṇhe
translated: how can we know you?”🔽“Whoever, in cold or heat,
in wind, sun, mosquitoes and creeping things,

original: Khudhaṁ pipāsaṁ abhibhuyya sabbaṁ,🔽Rattindivaṁ yo satataṁ niyutto.
analyzed: khudham pipāsam abhibhuyya  rattindivam yaḥ satatam niyuttaḥ
translated: Who is always intent day and night,

analyzed: kālāgatam ca na ha apa iti attha
translated: And does not miss the opportunity for benefit,

original: So me manāpo nivise ca tamhi;🔽Akkodhano mittavā cāgavā ca,🔽Sīlūpapanno asaṭhojubhūto.
analyzed: saḥ me manāpaḥ nivise ca tamhi  akkodhanaḥ mittavā ca āgavā ca  sīl upapannaḥ a saṭhaḥ ju bhūtaḥ
translated: Is pleasing to me and I live with him;🔽Who is without anger, has friends, is generous,🔽Has good conduct, is not deceitful, is upright,
Is inclusive, is gentle, has a soft voice,
And though of high rank, has a humble manner;
I support him with abundance,
Like the ocean with its waves.

original: Yo cāpi mitte atha vā amitte,
analyzed: yaḥ ca api mitte atha vā amitte
translated: And whether to friends or enemies,

analyzed: seṭṭhe sa rikkhe atha vā api hīne
translated: To the best, the equal, or even the inferior;
Whether he is doing good or bad,
I always keep him in secret.
I would never speak harsh words,
I am his mother and father in this life;

original: Etesaṁ yo aññataraṁ labhitvā,🔽Kantā sirī majjati appapañño;🔽Taṁ dittarūpaṁ visamaṁ carantaṁ,
analyzed: etesam yaḥ aññataram labhitvā  kantā sirī majjati appapaññaḥ  tam ditta rūpam visamam caranta
translated: He who, having obtained one of these,🔽Drowns in beauty and fame, being unwise;🔽I avoid him, who is seen to be behaving improperly,
Like a place of excrement.🔽One makes one’s own fortune,
one makes one’s own misfortune;

analyzed: na hi lakkhim a lakkhim vā
translated: For fortune and misfortune are not made by another,
one person does the work for another.”
The Birth Story of Sirikāḷakaṇṇi, the seventh.
